title: Will the Pakistan Muslim League (PML-N) win an overall majority of seats in the National Assembly in the 2018 general election?

PTI improving their position as polling day gets closer.

https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2018/07/18/no-single-party-can-form-govt-in-forthcoming-election-report-says/ KARACHI: No single party is likely to win an absolute majority to form government at the center, said AKD Securities report released before the July 25 polls on Wednesday. The Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaaf (PTI) can acquire 99 seats of the lower house against 27 won in 2013, while Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) is expected to win 72 lower house seats against 142 won in last elections out of the total 272 contested general seats, the report said.

PML-N will win majority of seats
Factors:
1) Corruption scandal 0.05 (tolerance toward corruption in Pakistan, one of the leaders in corruption list among countries)
2) Army interference 0.2
3) PTI activity 0.4
5) Good results of infrustructure projects 0.8
6) Return of Nawaz 0.75
7) Payment of a double bonus to civil servants before the elections 0.6
8) High level of povetry in Pakistan and chances of protests 0.1
9) Experience of PML-N party (in election, goverment, struggle etc) 0.7
Evidences:
1) Reducing in Gallup polls from 38% to 26% (6 june 2018)
2) High level of IPOR polls 32% (4 jule 2018)
3) Postive prediction from the Economist
Credability of evidence:
1) Big diverences between polls and voting results in previos period
2) IPOR polls have more participants and observations
3) No new information about polls after return of Nawaz
4) Vluctation of positive and negative news about PML-N and Nawaz
5) Pessimictic prediction from GJO (including men from Pakistan region)
6) Prediction from The Economist without updates

Dropping quite a bit because the PML-N is falling fast in polling.

www.geo.tv/latest/201653-elections-exclusive-3-poll-results-in-who-will-you-vote-for-pakistan  "While the Gallup survey still had the PML-N as the leading party for voter preference, it witnessed an 8% decrease from 2017, with 26% of respondents saying they would vote for the party in 2018. Voter preference for PTI was 25%, which was 1% decrease from 2017. 16% of respondents said they would vote for the PPP.  The PTI overtook the PML-N as the preferred party of voters in the Pulse survey. The PTI, which stood at 23% in 2017, saw a 7% increase with 30% of respondents saying they would vote for the party. The PML-N, which was in the lead in the 2017 survey, dropped 9% with 27% of respondents preferring to vote for the party. The PPP was the preferred party for 17% of respondents.  Surveys also found that undecided voters have emerged as a key battleground for political parties. Gallup poll shows this group to be at 20% as compared with 26% of respondents who would vote for the PML-N and 25% for the PTI at the national level. In the Pulse poll, the undecided voter group stands at 9% forming the fourth largest block after PTI at 30%, PML-N at 27% and Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) at 17%"

After Nawaz Sharif's disqualification PML-N's support has weakened, though only marginally. Still, Imran Khan's momentum and the expected higher number of independent candidates should keep the incumbent below the simple majority in the elections.
PML-N need 6 seats, but the recent legal controversy and leadship change make it more likely that they will lose seats.
Based on polling I still think the party comes out on top but I am now thinking their numbers don't quite get them a majority.

Pro:
1)	Opinion polls shows growth from 32.77% in 2013 to 38% in may 2018. Gallup Pakistan prediction/polling was positive for PML-N in 2013 election (their predictions were right). In election 2013 PML-N  had not 6 seats for majority with 32.77% (they had 166 seats), but now they have 38%. It has enhanced by 5% - approximately 8 potential seats, and there may be majority.
2)	Pakistan people will elect candidates from PML-N, but they will not elect Nawaz Sharif
3)	Nawaz Sharif scandal was in 2017, but opinion of Pakistan people about him is not very bad now. Nawaz had falls and rises before  - 1993, 2008, 2013. In several sources it said that it was unfair about corruption scandal with Nawaz.
4)	Wife’s memoirs about Imran Khan
5)	Culture differences from Europe and USA. Corruption scandals are disastrous for the political forces of Europe and the US, but in Pakistan not so
6)	The Economist Intelligence Unit expect the PML-N  to be reelected on the back of a strong showing in Punjab, the most populous province
7)	Low number of forecasters for that question in GJO 
8)	There is good news from dunyanews (local source of information) for PML-N Con:
1)	Corruption scandal has influence to election
2)	Problems with military men
3)	Reducing in voting intention in Punjab from 69% to 52%
4)	 Disabled Nawaz Sharif (he has good negotiator skills). But some times he can do it without power
5)	Low probability in GJO consensus for that question less than 6%. Khalid (GJO analytic) has 15% probability for that question (unknown biases about Pakistan politic)  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Pakistani_general_election,_2018

"Blow after blow dims re-election hopes of Pakistan's ruling party"
"In the past year, the PML-N party has seen a prime minister - its founder Nawaz Sharif - and foreign minister both ousted by the courts, while its finance minister, charged with corruption, fled the country. On Sunday (May 6), a gunman shot and wounded its interior minister.  All of this comes before another court ruling due this  month that could send Sharif to jail for 14 years over a corruption case he says is a “conspiracy” against him."
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-pakistan-politics-pmln-analysis/blow-after-blow-dims-re-election-hopes-of-pakistans-ruling-party-idUSKBN1IC0VS LATEST NEWS:  "Lawyers representing Pakistan’s ousted prime minister Nawaz Sharif have quit, leaving the former leader to face the final days of his trial on corruption charges without a legal team."
Mr Sharif could be jailed within days after his lawyers’ request for more time to set out his defence was rejected by the Supreme Court — the development that prompted them to resign.  
https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/nawaz-sharif-claims-foul-play-as-lawyers-quit-before-last-days-of-corruption-trial-jlwz3q0tr?CMP=Sprkr-_-Editorial-_-thetimes-_-Unspecified-_-TWITTER Sharif was denied a request to travel to London to visit his ailing wife who is being treated for cancer, is reportedly on a ventilator.  Most analysts predicting a hung parliament that will usher in a coalition government.

Previous victories have been built on a strong showing in the Punjab; this is now the focus of opposition efforts and PML-N defections. The party should win, but not with an overall majority.
...
Attempting to forecast the result of the elections is immensely difficult. Public opinion polling data in Pakistan is limited, constituency-level voting data from past elections are rarely made available beyond aggregate totals, and Pakistan’s history of electoral manipulation by both military and civilian governments means determinative interventions and mobilizations can often be carried out beyond the reach of open source reporting or analysis. 
https://www.usip.org/publications/2018/06/whats-stake-pakistans-summer-elections

KARACHI : The Economist Intelligence Unit recently put out its new Country Report for Pakistan, and despite criticism of the state of the economy, the report does not predict fair tidings for opposition political parties come July. The EIU predicts that risks to political stability will remain high in the run-up to the elections. “We expect the PML-N (Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz) to be reelected on the back of a strong showing in Punjab, the most populous province,” the report says.

They didn't achieve a majority last election and seem less likely to this election. "While the party should not be expected to produce a clear majority in the parliament, it should be able to attain an adequate number of National Assembly (NA) seats to become part of any negotiations to form the next government." - https://thediplomat.com/2018/06/mapping-the-road-to-pakistans-next-general-election/

Pakistan is run by a military government and democracy is allowed to a certain extent.  The Pakistan Muslim League (PML-N) was given enough rope to hang itself and it did.  Pakistan is the 6th most populated country on earth and no easy place to rule.  Corruption is what causes failed states and love it or hate it, civil rights are the sacrificial lamb if law and order are to be maintained in poor and dense countries.  There are nearly 200 million people in Pakistan and the population is growing at a 2% clip due to lack of industrialization.  A corrupt Pakistan is infinitely worse than a strong handed military dictatorship.  Steering an election in a favorable direction should be very doable for the powers at be.

The PML-N is still the most popular party according to opinion polls and while I can easily see them getting an overall majority, there is also a case to be made about their internal instability costing them seats.

The Pakistan Muslim League (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan_Muslim_League_(N)) currently has 178 out of the 342 seats in the Pakistan National Assembly (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Pakistan). It should also be noted that of those 342, only 272 are elected, with 70 reserved for women and religious minorities. "According to the constitution, the 70 seats reserved for women and religious minorities are allocated to the political parties according to their proportional representation." (Wikipedia)  I found this article from The Diplomat very insightful: https://thediplomat.com/2018/06/mapping-the-road-to-pakistans-next-general-election/ I won't bother to copy/paste the whole article out, but I will post some of the things that were interesting to me and that related to this question. ___________________________________ "Currently, the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N), which just concluded its term in office, appears to be a strong contender when it comes to forming the next government at the federal level. However, the party’s internal divisions, which may not have become public, are likely to cost it a large number of seats on election day. The party has not only lost major political heavyweights to other parties, but is also facing an internal succession crisis, which is only going to widen when the election period is over. The party’s former interior minister has decided to contest the next general election as an independent candidate, offering validation to already rampant fears that groupings in the party have developed to serious levels." "The PML-N’s internal divisions are only compounded by the military as well as the judiciary’s aversion toward the party’s leadership. During the last couple of years, both institutions have gone to lengths to not only question the PML-N’s governance priorities but have also made efforts to isolate the party’s role in national politics. Despite such efforts on the part of these two major state institutions, PML-N still remains relatively strong in terms of electoral politics. While the party should not be expected to produce a clear majority in the parliament, it should be able to attain an adequate number of National Assembly (NA) seats to become part of any negotiations to form the next government." __________________________________ Comments: "While the party should not be expected to produce a clear majority in the parliament" was the phrase that stood out to me most. However, I still put a 35% chance of getting a majority.
They could win the most seats but getting a majority would be a stretch, especially as it is becoming more and more obvious that the "deep state" wants to keep them out of power.
